Centre for People's Forestry.(Social actor - individual, groups, inst: Farmer Group (TFSC): Male Farmers, Female Farmers
Centre for People's Forestry.What did they do different? What was the: Started agroecological practice, crop diversification, water resource development and nutritional security amoung male and female farmers.
Centre for People's Forestry.Where did it happen? (Eg. Village / bloc: 25 Project Village in Ranibandh Block, Bankura District
Centre for People's Forestry.Outcome Statement: 1.        A total of 925 paddy farmers are adopting the System of Assured Rice Production (SARP) method across 977 bighas (326 acres) of land, with training provided on the use of bio-pesticides and bio-fertilizers. Additionally, 666 bighas of fallow land have been brought under cultivation with maize, black gram, and red gram.2.        220 acres (662 bighas) of land were cultivated with mustard, benefiting 670 farmers, while 206 acres (619 bighas) of land were used for food crops (cereals and pulses), also benefiting 670 farmers. Furthermore, 69.33 acres (208 bighas) of land were cultivated to vegetable cultivation, benefiting 323 farmers, with crops including cabbage, tomato, and cauliflower.3.        20 mobile vermicompost units were promoted, which will yield results, and 2 SMC structures were desilted and repaired.4.        The dietary habits of the community are shifting, with 400 farmers now growing a variety of vegetables in their household yards, thereby enhancing food security at the household level.5.        The transition to agroecological practices was facilitated through Farmer Field Schools and 51 demo plots, training 2,642 individuals on agroecological practices, crop-specific techniques, and crop diversification. Additionally, 2,462 farmers were trained in the preparation and application of Jeevamrutham, Neemastram, Agniastram, and Ganajeevamrutam, with 342 farmers actively using these methods.
Centre for People's Forestry.Why is this observation of change notewo: In West Bengal Paddy is the main crop and use huge level of pesticide, farmers are now shifting towards crop diversification and chemical free farming. This is becoming possible because of the Tribal Farmers Service Centre/ CBO getting established and they are adopting and spreading awareness about the agro ecological practices to other farmers.
Centre for People's Forestry.What do you think has contributed to thi: Input support and handholding support and training to farmers through demo plots and FFS have paved the way for this change. Motivating the communities through shramdan and financial contribution had resulted in communities owing of the project.
Centre for People's Forestry.Include links to any additional document: Photographs of fields. Maintained crop production data in excel and registered.

Sign of Hope + DRCSC.What did they do different? What was the: Applied and followed-up regarding important identity documents (ST certificates, Aadhaar cards etc.), and approached the Gram Panchayat through a group deputation to request for information camps about relevant govt. schemes. As a result, local Gram Panchayats and Block offices have been mobilized to organize varioussuch information camps. The communities have also been instrumental in spreading the knowledge and awareness gained to their peers within and beyond their village, helping more people to access these facilities.
Sign of Hope + DRCSC.Where did it happen? (Eg. Village / bloc: Kakdwip, Kultali, Sandeshkhali I and Hingalganj Blocks in the Indian Sundarbans
Sign of Hope + DRCSC.Outcome Statement: Since August 2023, indigenous communities in the Indian Sundarbans have been able to enhance their access to the available governement schemes and entitlements by effective engagement with the govt. line departments and PRI functionaries through strengthening village level women/youth groups, community institutions in the operational villages, and have increased their participation in local governance (Gram Panchayat etc.). Since August 2024, community visits to relevant government departments to seek information and assistance in accessing government benefits have increased, with no hesitation on their part.
Sign of Hope + DRCSC.Why is this observation of change notewo: It contributes to our outcome of strengthening indigenous communities' govt. participation and access to rights and govt. schemes with the participation of women. Through these efforts, the communities have become aware of their needs and govt. measures which can address some of those needs. Indigenous women have become proactive in accessing their rights and govt. facilities. Several community members who had applied to the Tribal Welfare Dept. for caste certification have received their certificates. In addition now PRI members, BDO and other relevant govt. officials have begun to train their focus on developmental initiatives at the village level so that nobody is left behind. The communities have continued to visit govt. camps, departments, and other relevant offices as needed, with no hesitation.
Sign of Hope + DRCSC.What do you think has contributed to thi: 1. Team members of DRCSC and LRRM  help the indigenous communities apply for their identity documents and follow-up with the local government to obtain these documents of the indigenous communities; and 2. Team members of DRCSC and LRRM provide technical support and guidance to the groups to prepare their application to the Gram Panchayat with their requests. Team members from DRCSC and LRRM have provided technical support and guidance to the groups in preparing their applications to the Gram Panchayat for their requests.

Sign of Hope + DRCSC.What did they do different? What was the: The indigenous communities received training in, and began to practice, climate resilient agriculture (using indigenous seeds, organic fertilisers and organic IPM, single stick paddy cultivation technique, maintaining nutrition gardens in their backyards etc.), and nutrition gardening following regular weather forecast and agro-advisory issued by the project's Information Hubs. They have begun to cultivate indigenous varieties of crops using seeds they received through the project and have also developed seed banks at the Information Hubs for future use. Seeds are also being saved at the household level as communities have become aware of their importance in sustainable agriculture. The communities have also began participatory shore protection through mangrove plantation and maintenance (using terracotta rings). Fishery/ Aquaculture trg
Sign of Hope + DRCSC.Where did it happen? (Eg. Village / bloc: Kakdwip, Kultali, Sandeshkhali I and Hingalganj Blocks in the Indian Sundarbans
Sign of Hope + DRCSC.Outcome Statement: Since April 2023, the indigenous communities have enhanced their climate resilience through climate-adaptive practices of agriculture and allied livelihood and sustainable natural resource management at the village level for food and income security.  Traditional paddy and pulses, are being cultivated organically, and organic fish farming/aquaculture is alo being done with organic inputs. Farmers also preserving their seeds.
Sign of Hope + DRCSC.Why is this observation of change notewo: It contributes to our outcome of enhanced climate resilience among the indigenous communities through climate-adaptive practices of agriculture and allied livelihood and sustainable natural resource management at the village level for food and income security. People preserving indigenious seeds at the household level has contributed to an increase in their control over farming. Women's decisionmaking agency has increased even in matters of agriculture, especially with regard to crop selection. Organic nutrition gardening has brought about a major positive change in the communities' food habits and nutrition intake as they now consume chemical-free produce and more vegetables and fruits than they did before. This has improved food and nutrition security in the project villages.   They regularly consume indigenous varieties of rice, pulses, animal protein, and a variety of vegetables, all organically grown on their own farms.
Sign of Hope + DRCSC.What do you think has contributed to thi: 1. Team members of DRCSC and LRRM provide training and handholding support in organic farming and nutrition gardening to the indigenous communities; 2. Team members of DRCSC and LRRM provide indigenous seeds to the communities; 3. Team members of DRCSC and LRRM provide regular weather foreecasts and agro-advisories; 4. Team members of DRCSC and LRRM provide wage, some materials (terracotta rings) and technical support to the communities for mangrove plantation through participatory shore protection.

Sign of Hope + DRCSC.(Social actor - individual, groups, inst: Indigenous communities in the 8 project villages
Sign of Hope + DRCSC.What did they do different? What was the: The indigenous communities were encouraged to preserve their rich linguistic and cultural heritage and take steps to arrest the loss of their language by ensuring that the children and youth learn their mother tongue. The communities were also encouraged to document their traditional song and dance performances on auspicious ocassions through photos, videos and audio recordings, which served as an encouragement to them, especially the younger generations, to practice the oral and performative aspects of their culture, which is also expected to contribute to improved mental, social, cultural and overall wellbeing of the communities. Women from the communities were provided training to provide informal mental health support within their villages since the mental healthcare framework in the Indian Sundarbans is extremely poor and largely inaccessible to these communities.
Sign of Hope + DRCSC.Where did it happen? (Eg. Village / bloc: Sundarbans Blocks Kakdwip, Kultali, Sandeshkhali I and Hingalganj
Sign of Hope + DRCSC.Outcome Statement: Since Oct 2022, the voices of the unheard indigenous communities in the Sundarbans are being strengthened through preservation of their linguistic and cultural heritage, and representation of their challenges and needs on public platforms (Sound of Silence project website, social media, photovoice and publications)
Sign of Hope + DRCSC.Why is this observation of change notewo: It contributes to our outcome of strengthened voices of the unheard indigenous communities in the Sundarbans through advocacy with govt. line depts., preservation of their linguistic and cultural heritage, and representation of their challenges and needs in public platforms (Sound of Silence project website, social media, photovoice and publications). The communities are actively celebrating their cultural heritage by commemorating World Indigenous Peoples' Day on August 9, 2024, and regularly performing music within their communities using dhamsa and madol provided by DRCSC and LRRM. These traditional percussion instruments hold deep cultural and spiritual significance for the tribal communities, serving as a vital part of their rituals, festivals, and social gatherings, reinforcing their collective identity and ancestral traditions.
Sign of Hope + DRCSC.What do you think has contributed to thi: 1. Team members of DRCSC and LRRM encourage the communitites to preserve their unique linguistic and cultural identity; 2. Team members of DRCSC and LRRM provide training to women of the indigenous communities to identify and provide informal support for mental health challenges in the village; 3. The project website and social media maintained by researchers from DRCSC and LRRM are updated with information and materials emerging from community interactions about community issues; 4. The team members of DRCSC and LRRM provide photovoice training to the indigenous youth to enable them to represent their lives and experiences through photovoice materials. DRCSC and LRRM provided musical instruments to the communities and encouraged them to continue celebrating their cultural heritage, speak their mother tongue, and pass it on to the younger generation.

Sign of Hope + DRCSC.What did they do different? What was the: Indigenous women formed mutual cooperation groups (MCGs) to undertake the project activities. They began to take decisions related to livelihood decisions (particularly agricultural practices), and have begun to contribute directly towards decisionmaking to improve the families' food and income security. They have also begun to receive training in identifying their own and others' mental health needs and providing informal mental health support to improve the communities' overall wellbeing.
